abstract.p: New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer letter disputes John Tierney Aug 8 column maintaining that recycling is 'hopelessly uneconomical' and that walking away from recycling might be better for environment

block.p: I take issue with John Tierney's implication that recycling is ''hopelessly uneconomical'' and that walking away from recycling might be better for the environment (Big City column, Aug. 8).

Too often, narrow cost-benefit analyses like Mr. Tierney's ignore the public health and environmental costs associated with the increased pollution from landfilling or burning solid waste rather than productively reusing it.
I take issue with John Tierney's implication that recycling is ''hopelessly uneconomical'' and that walking away from recycling might be better for the environment (Big City column, Aug. 8).

Too often, narrow cost-benefit analyses like Mr. Tierney's ignore the public health and environmental costs associated with the increased pollution from landfilling or burning solid waste rather than productively reusing it.

Recycling promotes sustainability and is good public policy. New Yorkers broadly support recycling, and my office has introduced two bills to enhance recycling in New York State. Recycling is also the law. My office has sued the upstate city of Amsterdam for abandoning its recycling program.
I call on every level of government to join me in a recommitment to recycling.
ELIOT SPITZER Attorney General, New York State Albany, Aug. 9, 2000
